This post gives a gentle introduction to the diffusion models, a family of the state of art generative model.

Theory

Diffusion model can be formulated as a Hierarchichal Variational Encoder (HVAE). To optimize variational auto-encoders, the critical technique is the use of evidence lower bound (ELBo) to estimate otherwise intractable distribution.

Eveidence Lower Bound (ELBo) and Vartiational Auto-encoder (VAE)

Given a variable xxx and its latent variable zzz, p(x)=∫p(x,z)dzp(x) = \int p(x, z) dzp(x)=∫p(x,z)dz However, the integration over all latent variables is intractable, so we introduce an encoder parametrized by ϕ\phiϕ, qϕ(z∣x)q_\phi(z| x)qϕ​(z∣x), to derive the evidence lower bound,

log⁡p(x)=log⁡∫p(x,z)dz=log⁡∫p(x,z)qϕ(z∣x)qϕ(z,x)dz=log⁡Eqϕ(z∣x)[p(x,z)qϕ(z∣x)]≥Eqϕ(z∣x)[log⁡(p(x,z)qϕ(z∣x))]=Eqϕ(z∣x)[log⁡(p(x∣z)p(z)qϕ(z∣x))]=Eqϕ(z∣x)[log⁡(p(x∣z))]+Eqϕ(z∣x)[log⁡(p(z)qϕ(z∣x))]=Eqϕ(z∣x)[log⁡(p(x∣z))]−DKL(qϕ(z∣x)∣∣p(z))\begin{aligned} \log p(x) &= \log \int p(x, z) dz \\ &= \log \int \frac{p(x, z)q_{\phi}(z|x)}{q_{\phi}(z, x)} dz \\ &= \log \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)} \Big[ \frac{p(x, z)}{q_{\phi}(z|x)} \Big] \\ &\geq \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)} \Big[ \log \Big(\frac{p(x, z)}{q_{\phi}(z|x)}\Big) \Big]\\ &= \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)} \Big[ \log \Big(\frac{p(x|z)p(z)}{q_{\phi}(z|x)}\Big) \Big]\\ &= \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)}\Big[ \log \Big( p(x|z) \Big) \Big] + \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)} \Big[ \log \Big(\frac{p(z)}{q_{\phi}(z|x)}\Big) \Big] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)}\Big[ \log \Big( p(x|z) \Big) \Big] - D_{\mathrm{KL}}(q_{\phi}(z|x)||p(z)) \end{aligned}logp(x)​=log∫p(x,z)dz=log∫qϕ​(z,x)p(x,z)qϕ​(z∣x)​dz=logEqϕ​(z∣x)​[qϕ​(z∣x)p(x,z)​]≥Eqϕ​(z∣x)​[log(qϕ​(z∣x)p(x,z)​)]=Eqϕ​(z∣x)​[log(qϕ​(z∣x)p(x∣z)p(z)​)]=Eqϕ​(z∣x)​[log(p(x∣z))]+Eqϕ​(z∣x)​[log(qϕ​(z∣x)p(z)​)]=Eqϕ​(z∣x)​[log(p(x∣z))]−DKL​(qϕ​(z∣x)∣∣p(z))​

For the variational auto-encoder, we also introduce a decoder parametrized by θ\thetaθ, pθ(z∣x)p_\theta(z|x)pθ​(z∣x), so the training objective becomes:

log⁡p(x)≥Eqϕ(z∣x)[log⁡(pθ(x∣z))]−DKL(qϕ(z∣x)∣∣p(z))\log p(x) \geq \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z|x)}\Big[ \log \Big( p_\theta(x|z) \Big) \Big] - D_{\mathrm{KL}}(q_{\phi}(z|x)||p(z))logp(x)≥Eqϕ​(z∣x)​[log(pθ​(x∣z))]−DKL​(qϕ​(z∣x)∣∣p(z))

In the training procedure, given a sample xxx, we obtain the encoding zzz by sampling from qϕ(z∣x)q_{\phi}(z|x)qϕ​(z∣x), and reconstruct a x′x'x′ by sampling from pθ(z∣x)p_\theta(z|x)pθ​(z∣x). The first term in ELBo is a reconstruction term, and the second term is a prior matching term. We usually assume zzz follows a simple distribution like a Gaussian distribution. In actual optimization, we use Montecarlo samples to estimate the expectation value.

Hierarchical VAE (HVAE)

One problem of VAE is that its prior distribution is usually very simple. To model more complex distributions, we can introduce TTT latent variables z1,…,zTz_1, \dots, z_Tz1​,…,zT​.

pθ(x,z1:T)=p(zT)pθ(x∣z1)∏t=2Tpθ(zt−1∣zt)qϕ(z1:T∣x)=qϕ(z1∣x)∏t=2Tqϕ(zt∣zt−1)\begin{aligned} p_{\theta}(x, z_{1:T}) &= p(z_T)p_{\theta}(x|z_1)\prod_{t=2}^{T} p_{\theta}(z_{t-1} | z_t) \\ q_{\phi}(z_{1:T}|x) &= q_{\phi}(z_1|x)\prod_{t=2}^{T} q_{\phi}(z_t | z_{t-1}) \end{aligned}pθ​(x,z1:T​)qϕ​(z1:T​∣x)​=p(zT​)pθ​(x∣z1​)t=2∏T​pθ​(zt−1​∣zt​)=qϕ​(z1​∣x)t=2∏T​qϕ​(zt​∣zt−1​)​

We can obtain a similar ELBo with Jensen’s inequality,

log⁡p(x)≥Eqϕ(z1:T∣x)[log⁡pθ(x,z1:T)qϕ(z1:T∣x)]\begin{aligned} \log p(x) \geq \mathbb{E}_{q_{\phi}(z_{1:T}|x)} \Big[ \log \frac{p_{\theta}(x, z_{1:T})}{q_{\phi}(z_{1:T}|x)} \Big] \end{aligned}logp(x)≥Eqϕ​(z1:T​∣x)​[logqϕ​(z1:T​∣x)pθ​(x,z1:T​)​]​

Diffusion Model as a HVAE

The most intuitive way to understand diffusion models is the process of gradually denoising a data sample into Gaussian noise, and the reverse process generates new data samples from Gaussian noise. Mathematically, the easist formulation of diffusion models is a special HVAE. In particular, instead of usual dimensionaly reduction in HVAE, each z1,…,zTz_1, \dots, z_Tz1​,…,zT​ has the same dimension as xxx. Therefore, we denote xxx with x0x_0x0​ instead, and z1,…,zTz_1, \dots, z_Tz1​,…,zT​ with x1,…,xTx_1, \dots, x_Tx1​,…,xT​. Further, we assume the encoder follows a fixed Gaussian distribution,

q(xt∣xt−1)=N(xt;αtxt−1,(1−αt)I)\begin{aligned} q(x_t|x_{t-1}) = \mathcal{N}(x_t; \sqrt{\alpha_t} x_{t-1}, (1-\alpha_t)I) \end{aligned}q(xt​∣xt−1​)=N(xt​;αt​​xt−1​,(1−αt​)I)​

where αt\alpha_tαt​ is a hyper-parameter.

Noising Encoder

We will show that after multiple encoding steps, the encoded sample is simply the original sample plus some Gaussian noise. Using the reparamatrization trick, we can write

q(xt∣xt−1)=αtxt−1+1−αtϵ0q(x_t|x_{t-1}) = \sqrt{\alpha_t} x_{t-1} + \sqrt{1-\alpha_t} \epsilon_0q(xt​∣xt−1​)=αt​​xt−1​+1−αt​​ϵ0​

where ϵ0∼N(ϵ0;0,1)\epsilon_0 \sim \mathcal N(\epsilon_0; 0, 1)ϵ0​∼N(ϵ0​;0,1)

By applying the encoder repeatedly, one can show that

xt=∏i=1tαix0+1−∏i=1tαiϵ0:=αˉtx0+1−αˉtϵ0∼N(xt;αˉtx0,(1−αˉt)I)\begin{aligned} x_t &= \sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{t} \alpha_i} x_0 + \sqrt{1 - \prod_{i=1}^{t} \alpha_i} \epsilon_0 \\ &:= \sqrt{\bar\alpha_t} x_0 + \sqrt{1-\bar\alpha_t} \epsilon_0 \\ &\sim \mathcal{N}(x_t; \sqrt{\bar\alpha_t} x_0, (1-\bar\alpha_t)I) \end{aligned}xt​​=i=1∏t​αi​​x0​+1−i=1∏t​αi​​ϵ0​:=αˉt​​x0​+1−αˉt​​ϵ0​∼N(xt​;αˉt​​x0​,(1−αˉt​)I)​

ELBo for Diffusion Model

Now we rewrite ELBo to decompose it into more intuitive terms,

log⁡p(x)≥Eq(x1:T∣x0)[log⁡pθ(x0,x1:T)q(x1:T∣x)]=Eq(x1∣x0)[log⁡pθ(x0∣x1)]−Eq(xT−1∣x0)[DKL(q(xT∣xT−1)∥p(xT))]−∑t=1TEq(xt−1,xt+1∣x0)[DKL(q(xt∣xt−1)∥pθ(xt∣xt+1))]\begin{aligned} \log p(x) &\geq \mathbb{E}_{q(x_{1:T}|x_0)} \Big[ \log \frac{p_{\theta}(x_0, x_{1:T})}{q(x_{1:T}|x)} \Big] \\ & = \mathbb{E}_{q(x_1|x_0)} \left[ \log p_{\theta}(x_0| x_1) \right] - \mathbb{E}_{q(x_{T-1}|x_0)} \left[ D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_T| x_{T-1}) \| p(x_T) \right) \right] \\ & \quad - \sum_{t=1}^{T} \mathbb{E}_{q(x_{t-1},x_{t+1}| x_0)} \left[ D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_t| x_{t-1}) \| p_{\theta}(x_t| x_{t+1}) \right) \right] \end{aligned}logp(x)​≥Eq(x1:T​∣x0​)​[logq(x1:T​∣x)pθ​(x0​,x1:T​)​]=Eq(x1​∣x0​)​[logpθ​(x0​∣x1​)]−Eq(xT−1​∣x0​)​[DKL​(q(xT​∣xT−1​)∥p(xT​))]−t=1∑T​Eq(xt−1​,xt+1​∣x0​)​[DKL​(q(xt​∣xt−1​)∥pθ​(xt​∣xt+1​))]​

Now the first term is the reconstruction term, which can be approximated and optimized using a Monte Carlo estimate. The second term is the prior matching term, but since our encoder and prior distribution is fixed, there are no parameters to optimize here. The new third term is the consistency term. With smarter term collection and cancellation, we decompose the ELBo differently so that each term is only an expectation over one random variable.

log⁡p(x)≥Eq(x1∣x0)[log⁡pθ(x0∣x1)]−DKL(q(xT∣x0)∥p(xT))−∑t=2TEq(xt∣x0)[DKL(q(xt−1∣xt,x0)∥pθ(xt−1∣xt))]\begin{aligned} \log p(x) &\geq \mathbb{E}_{q(x_1|x_0)} \left[ \log p_{\theta}(x_0| x_1) \right] - D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_T| x_0) \| p(x_T) \right) \\ &\quad - \sum_{t=2}^{T} \mathbb{E}_{q(x_{t}|x_0)} \left[ D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_{t-1}| x_t, x_0) \| p_{\theta}(x_{t-1}| x_t) \right) \right] \end{aligned}logp(x)​≥Eq(x1​∣x0​)​[logpθ​(x0​∣x1​)]−DKL​(q(xT​∣x0​)∥p(xT​))−t=2∑T​Eq(xt​∣x0​)​[DKL​(q(xt−1​∣xt​,x0​)∥pθ​(xt−1​∣xt​))]​

With the new derivation, we can understand the third term as a noise matching term, where pθ(xt−1∣xt)p_{\theta}(x_{t-1}| x_t)pθ​(xt−1​∣xt​) is estimating the noise added by xtx_txt​ and approximating the GT denoising fucntion q(xt−1∣xt,x0)q(x_{t-1}| x_t, x_0)q(xt−1​∣xt​,x0​) which has access to the data. We will now rewrite q(xt−1∣xt,x0)q(x_{t-1}| x_t, x_0)q(xt−1​∣xt​,x0​) to derive different training objectives of diffusion models.

1st Training Objective: Reconstruct Data Sample

We’ve already derived q(xt∣x0)q(x_t | x_0)q(xt​∣x0​), which is

q(xt∣x0)=αˉtx0+1−αˉtϵ0q(x_t | x_0) = \sqrt{\bar\alpha_t} x_0 + \sqrt{1-\bar\alpha_t} \epsilon_0q(xt​∣x0​)=αˉt​​x0​+1−αˉt​​ϵ0​

By Bayes rule and using the above fact with a lot of algebra, we can show that

q(xt−1∣xt,x0)=q(xt∣xt−1,x0)q(xt−1∣x0)q(xt∣x0)=q(xt∣xt−1)q(xt−1∣x0)q(xt∣x0)∝N(xt−1;αt(1−αˉt−1)xt+αˉt−1(1−αt)x01−αˉt,(1−αt)(1−αˉt−1)1−αˉtI):=N(xt−1;μq(xt,x0),σq2(t)I)\begin{aligned} q(x_{t-1}| x_t, x_0) &= \frac{q(x_{t}| x_{t-1}, x_0)q(x_{t-1}|x_0)}{q(x_t|x_0)} \\ &= \frac{q(x_{t}| x_{t-1})q(x_{t-1}|x_0)}{q(x_t|x_0)} \\ &\propto \mathcal{N}\Big(x_{t-1}; \frac{\sqrt{\alpha_t} (1-\bar{\alpha}_{t-1})x_t + \sqrt{\bar{\alpha}_{t-1}} (1-\alpha_t)x_0}{1-\bar{\alpha}_t} , \frac{(1-\alpha_t)(1-\bar{\alpha}_{t-1})}{1-\bar{\alpha}_t} I \Big) \\ &:= \mathcal{N}\Big(x_{t-1}; \mu_q(x_t, x_0), \sigma_q^2(t)I) \end{aligned}q(xt−1​∣xt​,x0​)​=q(xt​∣x0​)q(xt​∣xt−1​,x0​)q(xt−1​∣x0​)​=q(xt​∣x0​)q(xt​∣xt−1​)q(xt−1​∣x0​)​∝N(xt−1​;1−αˉt​αt​​(1−αˉt−1​)xt​+αˉt−1​​(1−αt​)x0​​,1−αˉt​(1−αt​)(1−αˉt−1​)​I):=N(xt−1​;μq​(xt​,x0​),σq2​(t)I)​

Set our decoder to be pθ(xt−1∣xt)=N(xt−1;μθ(xt,t),σq2(t)I)p_\theta(x_{t-1}|x_t) = \mathcal N(x_{t-1}; \mu_\theta(x_t, t), \sigma_q^2(t)I)pθ​(xt−1​∣xt​)=N(xt−1​;μθ​(xt​,t),σq2​(t)I), then we can use the DL divergence for Gaussians to derive,

arg min⁡θDKL(q(xt∣xt−1)∥pθ(xt∣xt+1))=arg min⁡θ12σq2(t)∣∣μθ−μq∣∣22\begin{aligned} \argmin_{\theta} D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_t| x_{t-1}) \| p_{\theta}(x_t| x_{t+1}) \right) &= \argmin_{\theta} \frac{1}{2\sigma_q^2(t)}||\mu_{\theta} - \mu_q||_2^2 \end{aligned}θargmin​DKL​(q(xt​∣xt−1​)∥pθ​(xt​∣xt+1​))​=θargmin​2σq2​(t)1​∣∣μθ​−μq​∣∣22​​

Finally, instead of predicting the mean μθ(xt,t)\mu_\theta(x_t, t)μθ​(xt​,t), we can directly predict the sample x^θ(xt,t)\hat x_\theta(x_t, t)x^θ​(xt​,t) and set the mean to match μq(xt,x0)\mu_q(x_t, x_0)μq​(xt​,x0​)

μθ(xt,t)=αt(1−αˉt−1)xt+αˉt−1(1−αt)x^θ(xt,t)1−αˉt\mu_\theta(x_t, t) = \frac{\sqrt{\alpha_t} (1-\bar{\alpha}_{t-1})x_t + \sqrt{\bar{\alpha}_{t-1}} (1-\alpha_t) \hat x_\theta (x_t, t)}{1-\bar{\alpha}_t}μθ​(xt​,t)=1−αˉt​αt​​(1−αˉt−1​)xt​+αˉt−1​​(1−αt​)x^θ​(xt​,t)​

Now substitue this assumption into the DL divergence term,

arg min⁡θDKL(q(xt−1∣xt,x0)∥pθ(xt−1∣xt))=arg min⁡θ12σq2(t)αˉt−1(1−αt)2(1−αˉt)2∣∣x^θ(xt,t)−x0∣∣22\begin{aligned} \argmin_{\theta} D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_t-1| x_t, x_0) \| p_{\theta}(x_t-1| x_{t}) \right) &= \argmin_{\theta} \frac{1}{2\sigma_q^2(t)} \frac{\bar{\alpha}_{t-1}(1-\alpha_t)^2}{(1-\bar{\alpha}_t)^2} ||\hat x_\theta (x_t, t) - x_0||_2^2 \end{aligned}θargmin​DKL​(q(xt​−1∣xt​,x0​)∥pθ​(xt​−1∣xt​))​=θargmin​2σq2​(t)1​(1−αˉt​)2αˉt−1​(1−αt​)2​∣∣x^θ​(xt​,t)−x0​∣∣22​​

Thus, the training objective becomes to predict the original data sample from a noisified version after ttt steps.

2nd Training Objective: Predicting Error

The most popular interpretation and the training objective in DDPM (Denoising Diffusion Probablistic Model), however, is to predict the noise in each denoising step. To derive this equivalent training objective, we need to rewrite μq(xt,x0)\mu_q(x_t, x_0)μq​(xt​,x0​) by substituting in x0=xt−1−αˉtϵ0αˉtx_0 = \frac{x_t-\sqrt{1-\bar\alpha_t}\epsilon_0}{\sqrt{\bar\alpha_t}}x0​=αˉt​​xt​−1−αˉt​​ϵ0​​.

μq(xt,x0)=αt(1−αˉt−1)xt+αˉt−1(1−αt)x01−αˉt=1αtxt−1−αt1−αˉtαtϵ0\begin{aligned} \mu_q(x_t, x_0) &= \frac{\sqrt{\alpha_t} (1-\bar{\alpha}_{t-1})x_t + \sqrt{\bar{\alpha}_{t-1}} (1-\alpha_t)x_0}{1-\bar{\alpha}_t} \\ & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}}x_t - \frac{1-\alpha_t}{\sqrt{1-\bar\alpha_t}\sqrt{\alpha_t}}\epsilon_0 \end{aligned}μq​(xt​,x0​)​=1−αˉt​αt​​(1−αˉt−1​)xt​+αˉt−1​​(1−αt​)x0​​=αt​​1​xt​−1−αˉt​​αt​​1−αt​​ϵ0​​

Now instead of predicting the sample x^θ(xt,t)\hat x_\theta(x_t, t)x^θ​(xt​,t), we predict the noise given a noised sample at time step ttt, ϵ^(xt,t)\hat\epsilon(x_t, t)ϵ^(xt​,t), and set

μθ(xt,t)=1αtxt−1−αt1−αˉtαtϵ^(xt,t)\mu_\theta(x_t, t) =\frac{1}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}}x_t - \frac{1-\alpha_t}{\sqrt{1-\bar\alpha_t}\sqrt{\alpha_t}}\hat\epsilon(x_t, t)μθ​(xt​,t)=αt​​1​xt​−1−αˉt​​αt​​1−αt​​ϵ^(xt​,t)

Now substitue this assumption into the DL divergence term,

arg min⁡θDKL(q(xt−1∣xt,x0)∥pθ(xt−1∣xt))=arg min⁡θ12σq2(t)(1−αt)2(1−αˉt)αt∣∣ϵ^θ(xt,t)−ϵ0∣∣22\begin{aligned} \argmin_{\theta} D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_{t-1}| x_t, x_0) \| p_{\theta}(x_{t-1}| x_{t}) \right) &= \argmin_{\theta} \frac{1}{2\sigma_q^2(t)} \frac{(1-\alpha_t)^2}{(1-\bar{\alpha}_t)\alpha_t} ||\hat \epsilon_\theta (x_t, t) - \epsilon_0||_2^2 \end{aligned}θargmin​DKL​(q(xt−1​∣xt​,x0​)∥pθ​(xt−1​∣xt​))​=θargmin​2σq2​(t)1​(1−αˉt​)αt​(1−αt​)2​∣∣ϵ^θ​(xt​,t)−ϵ0​∣∣22​​

Thus, the training objective becomes to predict the noise at a time step ttt.

3rd Training Objective: Predict the Score Function

In my opinion, the most profound understanding of diffusion models is that it is training a score function. Roughly speaking, the score function predicts the gradient field of a data distribution, so given any point, it predicts the direction to move into dense regions. To derive this formulation, we make use of the Tweedie’s Formula. Given z∼N(z;μz,Σz)z \sim \mathcal N(z; \mu_z, \Sigma_z)z∼N(z;μz​,Σz​),

E[μz∣z]=z+σz∇zlog⁡p(z)\mathbb E[\mu_z|z] = z + \sigma_z \nabla_z \log p(z)E[μz​∣z]=z+σz​∇z​logp(z)

Applying this formula, we have that

E[μxt∣xt]=xt+(1−αˉt)σxt∇zlog⁡p(xt)\mathbb E[\mu_{x_t}|x_t] = x_t + (1-\bar\alpha_t)\sigma_{x_t} \nabla_z \log p(x_t)E[μxt​​∣xt​]=xt​+(1−αˉt​)σxt​​∇z​logp(xt​)

We’ve drived that xt∼N(xt;αˉtx0,(1−αˉt)I)x_t \sim \mathcal N(x_t; \sqrt{\bar\alpha_t} x_0, (1-\bar\alpha_t)I)xt​∼N(xt​;αˉt​​x0​,(1−αˉt​)I), which gives us E[μxt∣xt]=αˉtx0E[\mu_{x_t}|x_t] = \sqrt{\bar\alpha_t}x_0E[μxt​​∣xt​]=αˉt​​x0​. Thus, we can rewrite x0x_0x0​ as

x0=xt+(1−αˉt)∇xtlog⁡p(xt)αˉtx_0 = \frac{x_t+(1-\bar\alpha_t) \nabla_{x_t}\log p(x_t)}{\sqrt{\bar\alpha_t}}x0​=αˉt​​xt​+(1−αˉt​)∇xt​​logp(xt​)​

Substitute this back into μq(xt,x0)\mu_q(x_t, x_0)μq​(xt​,x0​),

μq(xt,x0)=αt(1−αˉt−1)xt+αˉt−1(1−αt)x01−αˉt=1αtxt+1−αtαt∇xtlog⁡p(xt)\begin{aligned} \mu_q(x_t, x_0) &= \frac{\sqrt{\alpha_t} (1-\bar{\alpha}_{t-1})x_t + \sqrt{\bar{\alpha}_{t-1}} (1-\alpha_t)x_0}{1-\bar{\alpha}_t} \\ & = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}}x_t + \frac{1-\alpha_t}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}}\nabla_{x_t} \log p(x_t) \end{aligned}μq​(xt​,x0​)​=1−αˉt​αt​​(1−αˉt−1​)xt​+αˉt−1​​(1−αt​)x0​​=αt​​1​xt​+αt​​1−αt​​∇xt​​logp(xt​)​

Now instead of predicting the sample x^θ(xt,t)\hat x_\theta(x_t, t)x^θ​(xt​,t) or the noise ϵ^(xt,t)\hat\epsilon(x_t, t)ϵ^(xt​,t), we predict the score function sθ(xt,t)s_\theta(x_t, t)sθ​(xt​,t) to match ∇xtlog⁡p(xt)\nabla_{x_t} \log p(x_t)∇xt​​logp(xt​),

μθ(xt,t)=1αtxt+1−αtαtsθ(xt,t)\mu_\theta(x_t, t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}}x_t + \frac{1-\alpha_t}{\sqrt{\alpha_t}}s_\theta(x_t, t)μθ​(xt​,t)=αt​​1​xt​+αt​​1−αt​​sθ​(xt​,t)

Now substitue this assumption into the DL divergence term,

arg min⁡θDKL(q(xt−1∣xt,x0)∥pθ(xt−1∣xt))=arg min⁡θ12σq2(t)(1−αt)2αt∣∣sθ(xt,t)−∇xtlog⁡p(xt)∣∣22\begin{aligned} \argmin_{\theta} D_{\text{KL}}\left(q(x_{t-1}| x_t, x_0) \| p_{\theta}(x_{t-1}| x_{t}) \right) &= \argmin_{\theta} \frac{1}{2\sigma_q^2(t)} \frac{(1-\alpha_t)^2}{\alpha_t} ||s_\theta (x_t, t) - \nabla_{x_t} \log p(x_t)||_2^2 \end{aligned}θargmin​DKL​(q(xt−1​∣xt​,x0​)∥pθ​(xt−1​∣xt​))​=θargmin​2σq2​(t)1​αt​(1−αt​)2​∣∣sθ​(xt​,t)−∇xt​​logp(xt​)∣∣22​​

Guidance for Generation

Now everthing is great. We can either train a neural network to predict sample from Gaussian samples, or to predict noise and denoise, or to predict the score function. What if we want to guide the generation given some prior information, say we want to generate a cat but we train on all kinds of animals? The two main guidance methods are classifer guidance and classifer-free guidance.

Classifer Guidance

More concretely, given some prior yyy to condition on, we want to generate a sample according to p(x0∣y)p(x_0 | y)p(x0​∣y). Let’s decompose this using the Bayes’ rule,

p(xt∣y)=p(xt)p(y∣xt)p(y)p(x_t |y) = \frac{p(x_t)p(y|x_t)}{p(y)}p(xt​∣y)=p(y)p(xt​)p(y∣xt​)​

and the score function is

∇xtp(xt∣y)=∇xtp(xt)+∇xtp(y∣xt)−∇xtp(y)=∇xtp(xt)+∇xtp(y∣xt)\begin{aligned} \nabla_{x_t} p(x_t|y) &= \nabla_{x_t}p(x_t) + \nabla_{x_t} p(y|x_t) - \nabla_{x_t} p(y) \\ &=\nabla_{x_t}p(x_t) + \nabla_{x_t} p(y|x_t) \end{aligned}∇xt​​p(xt​∣y)​=∇xt​​p(xt​)+∇xt​​p(y∣xt​)−∇xt​​p(y)=∇xt​​p(xt​)+∇xt​​p(y∣xt​)​

The first term is the usual unconditional score, and the second term is an adversarial gradient of a classifer p(y∣xt)p(y|x_t)p(y∣xt​). Thus, in practice, we can train a classifier for each class yyy to guide the generation process.

To gain fine-grained control over the guidance, we can introduce a hyperparameter γ\gammaγ to scale the adversarial gradient,

∇xtp(xt∣y)=∇xtp(xt)+γ∇xtp(y∣xt)\nabla_{x_t} p(x_t|y) = \nabla_{x_t}p(x_t) + \gamma \nabla_{x_t} p(y|x_t)∇xt​​p(xt​∣y)=∇xt​​p(xt​)+γ∇xt​​p(y∣xt​)

Classifer-free Guidance

Nevertheless, it’s costly and even impossible to train a classifer for each new condition. To introduce classifer-free guidance, we rewrite the scaled conditional score,

∇xtp(xt∣y)=∇xtp(xt)+γ∇xtp(y∣xt)=∇xtp(xt)+γ(∇xtp(xt∣y)−∇xtp(xt))=γ∇xtp(xt∣y)+(1−γ)∇xtp(xt)\begin{aligned} \nabla_{x_t} p(x_t|y) &= \nabla_{x_t}p(x_t) + \gamma \nabla_{x_t} p(y|x_t) \\ &= \nabla_{x_t}p(x_t) + \gamma (\nabla_{x_t} p(x_t|y) - \nabla_{x_t} p(x_t)) \\ &= \gamma \nabla_{x_t} p(x_t|y) + (1-\gamma) \nabla_{x_t} p(x_t) \end{aligned}∇xt​​p(xt​∣y)​=∇xt​​p(xt​)+γ∇xt​​p(y∣xt​)=∇xt​​p(xt​)+γ(∇xt​​p(xt​∣y)−∇xt​​p(xt​))=γ∇xt​​p(xt​∣y)+(1−γ)∇xt​​p(xt​)​

The first term is the conditional score, and the second term is the unconditional score. In practice, we can train a neural network that always takes in a conditional imformation (which is empty for unconditional score).
